climbs.name: Backscratcher
climbs.fa: Put up by Tyler and Wolfgang, FA Lesley Winterhalt

content.description:
Named so because of a tree that stands behind you as you begin the climb, if you lean back you will get a sappin' and a scratchin'. Start in the broken fingers to hands crack which sweeps up left to a shallow corner. Gain the ledge above and pull a ninja move past a splitter fingers section to an easy short crack above. Don't touch the big blocks above the anchor, they look sketchy

Start directly in front of the tree on the left side of the wall.
Two hangars with rings at top. Gear to 4" (easily done with 3")

Start up the off-width crack, jamming and stemming, gradually narrowing to fists. Pull through steep flakes to a good stance on the right. Cast off into the splitter right-arching finger crack on upper wall (thin gear) with a pumpy traverse to a stance. Follow the vertical finger cracks to the top, then step right to belay off the “Loose Tooth” bolted anchors.

Descent: Rappel ‘Loose Tooth" and "One Who Flew Over the Hornets Nest’ or walk off down the Shangri-La (Tip of the Sword) approach trail.

This is a newer climb so more ascents should help narrow down the grade!

Climb “One Who Flew Over the Hornets Nest” and instead of gaining the big ledge, go left to the base of a wide crack in the right facing corner.
Gear to 5"

climbs.name: Escape Pod
climbs.fa: Put up by Tyler and Wolfgang, FA Tim Russell

content.description:
Climb a long easy and pleasant section of upturned flakes to a steep defined crux section split by a thin crack. The crux here involves small flakes, a reach up to a small pod and diminished footholds or a foot sling. It is worth pulling through the crux on draws for the rest of the climb but it is still a trick. The upper crack is a fun finish. Don't mess with the big scary blocks above.

Beginning just to the right of Backscratcher in front of obvious flakes.
Two hangars with rings at top. Bolted.

If accessing this climb from Shangri-Low you arrive at the top of P1.

P1. - 5.9, 25m. Start in a steep blocky corner to gain the crack that will take you to a nice belay ledge with bolted anchors-

P2. - 5.10a, 40m. Straight up from anchors on low angle rock, climb short crack and corner system on steeper terrain. Continue straight up with a thrutchy move into a wide crack. An easier alternative is to traverse right and use the ramp to gain the ledge above
the wide crack. A couple more moves will take you to the top of the buttress.

Descent : You will find webbing around a tree with rings to use for a rappel., two ropes are required to rappel this pitch.

Head to the far right of the Shangri-Low wall and this climb is just before the fixed rope to take you over to Shangri-La.
Gear to 4'.

Description to follow.  This climb serves as access to Shangri-La without hiking around.

Climb up One Who Flew Over the Hornets Nest and trend right to gain the big ledge.
Gear to 3". Bolted anchor with rings

climbs.name: New Age Hippies Eat Croissants
climbs.fa: Put up by Wolfgang, Tyler, FA Wolfgang

content.description:
Because it's so flaky. Clip the bolt under the roof but step out and left to climb the large gong flake. Continue up the left side of the arete on flake jugs while clipping bolts on the right side of the arete (where the rock was better). As the flakes disappear, step around the arete onto the right face and continue up on small holds. The defined crux arrives after clipping two more bolts. After the short crux, finish on fun tricky slab bulges to the anchors. Possible pull through the crux on draws.The grade for this climb is height dependent 5.11a for those of us with shorter wingspan and, 5.10a for the rest.

Just to the right of Pitch 15.
Two hangars with rings at top. Bolted. Height of climb isn't exactly known so tie a knot just in case.

climbs.name: One Who Flew Over the Hornets Nest

content.description:
Description to follow. When combined with Loose Tooth these climbs serve as a possible access to Sangri-La wall.

Walk the the far right of the wall and it's the last climb you see.
gear to 3". Bolted anchor with rings.

Named for the right-left traverse mid-climb which yields the sensation of being on Dawn Wall. Start up the shallow flaky right facing corner. Step out left and do a short traverse to right facing flakes. Embody your inner spirit ape and monkey up and right before heading for the anchors. Grade is still up for debate as either 5.9 or 5.10a.

This is the steep improbable bolt line in front of you as you step up on the ledge.
Bolted anchor with rings. Fully Bolted.

Once you make the trek above you are four steep climbs of varying difficulty. To the left there is one trad climb and to the right three sport pitches. You should see bolts. Continue just around the corner to several other great climbs and the glory that is Shangri-la.
